channel.title: For my simulation
channel.description: Ok. I have gotten a fair amount of work down to read and write text documents. I also have a method to run 300 ticks per cycle of 4 cycles. My first question is I want to set a timer so that there is 1 tick per second. Do i put the timer inside of the loop i used or do I put the timer with in one of the four cycle loops? I have considered implementing Grahams eventmanager and eventcycler to help with this all. My second question is if it is possible to define a line and cirles that bounce around in a given square. The line would be clipped and so would the boarders of the square the the circles woulden't pass over them. The thing about the line is there would be 2-3 wholes in the line to be the 'permeable membrane.' My simulation is on reverse osmosis and i can't get the GUI part to work so I thought i would get the data to be copied onto a text document and then graph it. Thanks for the help.

item.title: For my simulation
item.dc:creator: @RiiPiiNFtW RiiPiiNFtW
item.description:
@RiiPiiNFtW wrote:

Wait whose a faggot?! And i already figured that out.

OT: I am trying to loop it to tick 1 second per sending out a level.logger(INFO, " ");

This is my main.java ATM, [code=java]
import java.util.logging.;
import java.util.Timer;
import java.lang.System;
import java.io.;

/**

  • Reverse Osmosis
  • @author Stuart Perera
  • @version 1.2.1
  • @created 1/12/12
    */

public class Main {

private static final Logger logger = Logger.getLogger(Main.class.getName());

private final static FileData fd = new FileData();

private static int simulationDelay;

private static double cycleRate;

public static void main(String... args) throws IOException {
	int k;
	int totalRun = 1200;
	simulationDelay = 1000;
	for (k = 0; k < totalRun; k++) {
	logger.log(Level.INFO, "Reverse Osmosis Simulation has Started.");
	FileData.main(args);
	int numberOfCycles = 1;
	for (k = 0; k < numberOfCycles; k++) {
		debug();
	}
	logger.log(Level.INFO, "Reverse Osmosis cycle ended.");
}
}

public static void debug(String... args) throws IOException {
	int numberOfCycles = 1000;
	if (numberOfCycles >  1000) {
		int cycles = 300;
		int totalCycleTime = 1000;
		final long averageCycleTime = totalCycleTime / cycles;
		simulationDelay = (int) System.currentTimeMillis();
		System.out
				.println("Average Cycle Time: " + averageCycleTime + "ms");
	}
}

public static FileData getFd() {
	return fd;
}

}
[/code] I know I did something wrong, Help though. I am not all that good at ticks:P

Read full topic

item.title: For my simulation
item.dc:creator: @RiiPiiNFtW RiiPiiNFtW
item.description:
@RiiPiiNFtW wrote:

Ok. Thanks

On an update, I am trying to implement a timer using a public long for example:

static long simulationDelay; int k; int numberOfCycles = 1200; for (k = 0; k < numberOfCycles; k++) { System.currentTimeMillis() - simulationDelay == 1200; FileData.main(args); } or would i use long simulationDelay = System.currentTimeMillis(); ? Thanks for helping.

Read full topic

item.title: For my simulation
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

Matters upon where you define the origin of the shape and if you use the java implementation for sketching graphics. Could just implement a simple clipping box where before you move the shape you check to see if the box is beyond the limits of a clip and then appropriately draws it. There are many ways you can accomplish this and personally I would take the clipping box and custom drawing implementation.

Do the math.

Also:

java.util.concurrent <- Is your friend.

Read full topic
